prelude.value: There’s no comprehensive way to measure gayborhoods or even where LGBT Americans live. The US Census has never asked questions about sexual orientation and gender identity and the department scrapped proposed questions to do so for the 2020 Census. To try to get a little bit closer to a complete picture, several metrics were combined to create a gayborhoods index: same-sex unmarried partner households (US Census, 2015), same-sex married joint tax filers (US Treasury Department, 2015), Pride Parade routes (2018), and Yelp businesses tagged “gay bars” (2018).
The numbers used are not without their own shortcomings (you can read more about them in the methodology section), but they are still some of the most reliable data we have on the LGBT community.

stepOne.value: New York City’s Pride march route snakes its way through the city’s historic gayborhood in the West Village, running right by the Stonewall Inn on Christopher Street, the site of the 1969 riots that helped launch the gay rights movement.

stepTwo.value: The city’s gay bars are clustered on the west side of Manhattan in the West Village, Chelsea and upper Hell’s Kitchen.

stepThree.value: So it’s no surprise that when combined with data on where same-sex couples live these same areas are also highlighted. But there are also darker areas that stretch out into Brooklyn. Let’s look at how this differs by gender:

stepFour.value: The area with the highest concentration of male same-sex couples mirrors the overall gayborhood index. Men congregate where the majority of the bars are.

stepFive.value: When we look at female same-sex couples, we see a different pattern. Although there is some overlap with male couples up the west side of Manhattan, female same-sex couples are overall less concentrated with the strongest cluster appearing in Park Slope, Brookyn.

city.text:
Atlanta, one of the nation’s largest black-majority cities, has a storied history of civil rights activism and has long been an oasis for minorities in the South. Many prominent figures from the city, including Coretta Scott King, have drawn a line between the common struggle for blacks and gays. At a 1986 Human Rights Campaign dinner, King affirmed her “solidarity with the gay and lesbian movement.”

Today, Atlanta’s gayborhood in Midtown is permanently marked by a rainbow crosswalk at the intersection of 10th Street and Piedmont Ave. But some residents see the crosswalk as a “headstone” for the area, a physical memorial of the de-gaying of the gayborhood as housing booms, rents rise, and straight couples move in. Katharine, 32, said “The reason minorities live in the city is it’s a safe space. It’s a struggle to be pushed out.”

Houston’s gayborhood is southwest of downtown in the Montrose neighborhood, but the area is currently undergoing a lot of shifts. In 2015, the Pride parade was moved out of Montrose, its home for 36 years, and moved downtown. Malone, 30, who’s first Pride parade was Houston’s last in Montrose, said that at last year’s celebration she marched topless, “Downtown I couldn’t leave the parade route without putting my shirt on. When it was in Montrose, I could just walk in a bar with my nipple pasties on and not get hollered at.”

Montrose is home to a clustering of gay bars between Fairview and Pacific streets and Grant and Hopkins streets. But just a couple streets over new restaurants and sports bars touting craft beer and late-night eats cater to a different clientele. The LGBT community is even trying to reclaim one such bar named the Hay Merchant by calling it the “Gay Merchant.”

As Montrose evolves, Houston’s LGBT community has also started to settle in neighborhoods southeast of downtown like Third Ward and East Downtown and areas to the north like the Heights. Outside the city’s interstate loop is another story. John, 33, said “It’s like the Lion King meme, ‘What’s that dark place outside of Loop 610? We don’t go there.’” Houston’s got a long history of being progressive on LGBT issues: it became the largest city in the US to elect an openly gay mayor with Annise Parker in 2009 and its home to the GLBT Political Caucus, the South’s oldest LGBT civil rights group. But, Houston’s still in Texas, and Texas is still trying to pass “bathroom bill” laws

In the 1990s, sun-soaked Miami gained popularity for a much darker reason. Many HIV positive men made the move to South Beach expecting to die. Miami was a popular destination because of its warm climate and cheap cost of living. As AIDS awareness and medicine improved, this community of gay men made Miami their permanent home.

Miami’s gayborhood is off the mainland on Miami Beach, where there’s a strip of gay bars and the Pride parade runs down Ocean Drive. Miami resident Chris, 33, says the area is home to gay men on all points of the flamboyant and feminine spectrums. Noticeably absent from the LGBT community in Miami? Women. Miami has zero zip codes that register on the female gayborhood index. Miami’s gayborhood, like many big city gayborhoods, has been confronted with rising rents and increasing diversity, but it’s also been exacerbated by a spike in tourism to the south Florida city.

These shifts have pushed some former Miami residents to relocate an hour up the coast to Fort Lauderdale. Miami also competes with Key West and Key Largo as a top LGBT destination.

Philly officially designated an area in Washington Square West from 11th to Broad streets and Pine to Locust as the “Gayborhood” in 2007 (it even appears in Google Maps.), but it’s unofficially been the gay epicenter for decades. It’s home to a dense cluster of bars and anchor institutions like the William Way LGBT Community Center and an outpost of the Mazzoni Center, a healthcare provider for the LGBT community.

A string of incidents in 2016 is forcing Philly’s Gayborhood to confront racism and a lack of intersectionality, but the “City of Brotherly Love” is working to make its LGBT community more inclusive, launching the #MoreColorMorePride campaign and unveiling a new rainbow flag with black and brown stripes added.

Philly resident, Thom, 31, said it’s important to him to have an area where he feels comfortable walking down the street holding his boyfriend’s hand, but he recognizes the Gayborhood might not feel like a safe space for everyone. “If we want people to be invested in these communities we need to create safe spaces for everyone. At the same time, people are doing this without those neighborhoods.” Newer LGBT enclaves are emerging in West Philly (which didn’t appear on our map) and to the north in Germantown and Mount Pleasant where there is a higher concentration of same-sex female couples.

Portland routinely appears on lists of cities with the largest LGBT populations, but it doesn’t have a defined gayborhood. Portland resident David, 40, said “Sometimes I wonder if Portland is the almost the ideal actualized city. There isn’t a central space, but people are welcome and diluted throughout the city.”

Stark Street is still the downtown nightlife destination, but the southwest are known as the “Pink Triangle” or “Vaseline Alley” is a shadow of its former self. Anchor bars began closing one-by-one in the mid 2000s to make way for new development. Economic forces play a part in the area’s transformation, as do wide social acceptance in Portland and technology. David said it wasn’t uncommon to go to bar and see “80 percent of the guys on their phones.”

Portland’s gayborhood index maps show that the entire city could be considered a gayborhood. The most noticeable difference between the two genders is that there is a higher concentration of same-sex male couples downtown in the Pearl District. Men also tend to live northwest of the city, and women to the northeast.

Dupont, the nation’s capital gayborhood, is draped in rainbow. But, DC area resident Alissa, 27, says that’s true of pretty much all of Washington, “The whole city is gay. It’s hard to go anywhere without seeing a pride flag.” That wide acceptance coupled with economic development and rising rents has decentralized the gayborhood — a trend seen across the nation.

Town Danceboutique, a popular gay dance bar will close on July 1 to make way for an apartment complex. Phase 1, DC’s last lesbian bar, closed in 2016. “I think there’s a juice bar or something there now,” said Alissa. Ed, 54, who moved to DC the first time in 1989 said that technology is also having an effect. “Dupont used to be the place to be, but it’s an app world now. You don’t need a queer friendly bar to meet people.”

Currently a large concentration of same-sex male couples still call Dupont home and are spilling into Shaw, a traditionally black neighborhood. Same-sex female couples are clustered just north in Adams Morgan and Columbia Heights and have spilled across the northeast border into Maryland. Maryland was seen as a cheaper, more liberal choice than the capital’s other neighbor, Virginia. Same-sex couples were able to get married in Maryland a year and 10 months before they were in Virginia.

methodology.value: Here’s what’s included in the index:

metrics.dataDesc: Because marriages are tracked at the state level, not federally, the US Treasury Department Office of Tax Analysis linked tax returns with social security numbers to give us the best picture of same-sex marriage in the states.

Since the Census doesn’t ask specifically about LGBT Americans, we’re forced to use same-sex unmarried partner households as a proxy. The Census currently reclassifies married same-sex married households as unmarried partners.
Pride parade routes often touch historic gayborhoods within cities. The routes have been used to identify culturally significant areas.
Bar locations can help define a commercial corridor for LGBT communities. Businesses tagged “gay bar,” “lesbian bar,” and “gay and lesbian bar” where included.
